body_html:
Hi @Srigowri, if you want to run the code without Docker you can just install TensorFlow locally on your machine.
Regarding CPU or GPU both would work for the purpose of running the code, it will depend if you have a compatible GPU and CUDA and cuDNN installed. All the details on how to use TensorFlow with GPU support are on https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_windows.

To use the code with your images one way is to set the default folder path to where your images are stored here. The other way, which is recommended is to use --image_dir as instructed in the codelab.

You will need Bazel for Windows to build the retrainer so just copying the folder won't work. You can download Bazel here. Make sure to properly add the Bazel binary directory to your %PATH%. To set where the graph will be created you may use output_graph and output_labels.

Let's sum it up:

  1. Install TensorFlow
  2. Download Bazel and add its directory to %PATH%
  3. Retrieve the model files
  4. Build it with Bazel
  5. Go through this section to learn how to classify new images with the retrainer. You can read the # In Docker comments as "in your command prompt".
  6. Then here to learn about training categories you want.

If you have any further questions feel free to ask.

You will need Bazel for Windows to build the retrainer so just copying the folder won't work. You can download Bazel here. Make sure to properly add the Bazel binary directory to your %PATH%. To set where the graph will be created you may use output_graph and output_labels.
Let's sum it up:

Install TensorFlow
Download Bazel and add its directory to %PATH%
Retrieve the model files
Build it with Bazel
Go through this section to learn how to classify new images with the retrainer. You can read the # In Docker comments as "in your command prompt".
Then here to learn about training categories you want.

If you have any further questions feel free to ask.
body:
Hi @Srigowri, if you want to run the code without Docker you can just install TensorFlow locally on your machine. 
Regarding CPU or GPU both would work for the purpose of running the code, it will depend if you have a compatible GPU and CUDA and cuDNN installed.  All the details on how to use TensorFlow with GPU support are on https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_windows.

To use the code with your images one way is to set the default folder path to where your images are stored [here](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/examples/image_retraining/retrain.py#L903). The other way, which is recommended is to use `--image_dir` as instructed [in the codelab](https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/tensorflow-for-poets/#6).

You will need Bazel for Windows to build the retrainer so just copying the folder won't work. You can download Bazel [here](https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/releases). Make sure to properly add the Bazel binary directory to your `%PATH%`. To set where the graph will be created you may use `output_graph` and `output_labels`.

Let's sum it up:
1. Install TensorFlow 
2. Download Bazel and add its directory to `%PATH%`
3. Retrieve the model files
4. [Build it with Bazel](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/examples/image_retraining/retrain.py#L42)
5.  Go through [this section](https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/tensorflow-for-poets/#4) to learn how to classify new images with the retrainer. You can read the `# In Docker` comments as "in your command prompt".
6. Then [here](https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/tensorflow-for-poets/#6) to learn about training categories you want.

If you have any further questions feel free to ask.
